Award.AwardTitle: Impactathons: Student-Led Peer-to-Peer Learning in Community Social-Change Technology Projects

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This pilot study will examine the effectiveness of an innovative applied social change, community and technology based program on marginalized youths' access, interest, efficacy and motivation to learn and engage in digital technology applications. Using stratified near-peer and peer-to-peer mentoring approaches, the pilot builds on extant literature that indicates that peer-supported hands-on mentoring and experiences can alleviate some barriers to youth engagement in digital technologies, particularly among underrepresented groups. In this project, undergraduate students will mentor and work collaboratively with high school youth primarily of Hispanic descent and community-based organizations to develop creative technology-based solutions to address social issues and challenges within their local communities, culminating in events called Impactathons. These community-hosted local and state-wide events set this pilot project apart from similar work in the field. The Impactathons not only provide a space for intellectual discourse and problem-solving among the undergraduate-youth-community partners but the Impactathons will also codify expertise from scientists, social scientists, technologists, community leaders, and other stakeholders to develop technology-based solutions with real world application. If successful, a distal outcome will be increased youth interest in digital technologies and related fields. In the short term, favorable findings will provide preliminary evidence of success and lay the foundation for a more extensive study in the future.

This pilot project is a collaboration between the Everett Program, a student-led program for Technology and Social Change at the University of California Santa Cruz - a Hispanic Serving Institution - and the Digital NEST, a non-profit, high-tech youth career development and collaboration space for young people ages 14-24. Through this partnership and other recruitment efforts, an estimated 70-90 individuals will participate in the Impactathon pilot program over two years. Nearly two-thirds of the participants are expected to be undergraduate students. They will receive extensive training in near-peer and peer-to-peer mentoring and serve as mentors for and co-innovation developers with the high school youth participants. The undergraduates and youth will partner with local community organizations to identify a local social challenge that can be addressed through a technology-based solution. The emergent challenges will vary and could span the spectrum of STEM and applied social science topics of interest. Working in informal contexts (i.e., afterschool. weekend), the undergraduate-youth-community partner teams will work collaboratively to develop practical technology-based solutions to real world challenges. The teams will convene three times per year, locally and statewide, at student and community led Impactathons to share their work and glean insights from other teams to refine their innovations. In parallel, the research team will examine the effectiveness of the Impactathon model in increasing the undergraduate and youths' interest, motivation, excitement, engagement and learning of digital technologies. In addition to the research, the formative and summative evaluations should provide valuable insights on the effectiveness of the model and its potential for expansion and replication.

The project is co-funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) Program and STEM +C. The AISL program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. STEM + C focuses on research and development of interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary approaches to the integration of computing within STEM teaching and learning for preK-12 students in both formal and informal settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to improve our understanding of factors that can help overcome barriers that marginalized populations face in learning and using digital technologies.  Women and certain racial groups (African-Americans, Latinos and Native Americans) remain significantly under-represented in their knowledge and use of digital technologies. Research has shown that this under-representation can be traced in part to subtle culturally-rooted communication processes, between under-represented youth and their teachers or other adults, that undermine motivation and confidence in their own learning abilities. Research has also shown that peer-to-peer and near-to-peer training can be effective in over-coming these barriers, especially in applied learning contexts where newcomers get peer-supported hands-on experience.

Our project was developed as a collaboration between the Everett Program for Technology and Social Change at UC Santa Cruz and the Digital NEST in Watsonville. It helped investigate an innovative new structure for informal technology learning focused on student-led, peer-to-peer communication in applied social change projects. The structure starts with college students and community youth collaboratively organizing "Everett Impactathons"--intensive one- or two-day hackathon-like events focused on social change goals of community partners.  Everett Impactathons have a well-structured cycle--from needs assessment, through planning & design and implementation, to knowledge consolidation--over an annual calendar that allows students and youth to develop higher and higher levels of skills and experience that build their confidence and success over the timeframe of their informal learning experience.

Though building on years of related experience of the project partners, these learning processes are also highly replicable in other contexts of University-community collaborations.  A formal external evaluation of this program concluded that "Everett Impactathons show promise as a method for increasing young peoples' learning and interest in using technology for social change."  Impactathons can help reach youth whose prior access to technology was limited, but who were interested in social change and technology. Learning about technology in the context of learning about social justice issues and how technology can be used for social good helps inspire youth to learn more about technology and to teach themselves new tech skills.

One of the outcomes of this project is a detailed set of resources and toolkits available for other organizations who are interested in organizing their own Impactathon-like events.  Available at https://www.impactathons.org/, The website includes a variety of different materials, including:

  • Detailed descriptions of the Everett Impactathon model, and evidence from our evaluation of their impact
  • A 'learning library' that includes detailed descriptions, curriculum material and associated Impactathon web-sites for all 6 Impactathons developed and run through this NSF-funded project
  • A detailed tool-kit for other educators to help develop their own Impactathons, including detailed project planning guides and resources for planning, facilitating, recruiting and evaluating such events.

More broadly, this project provides evidence to help fill gaps in our knowledge of factors shaping the ability of disadvantaged populations to overcome "digital production divides": the ability to not just have access to digital technologies, but to effectively use and develop digital technologies to produce content, improve efficiency in information processing and communication activities, and address social issues that are most relevant to disadvantaged people and communities.  This project helped evaluate the effectiveness of peer-to-peer and near-to-peer out-of-school applied learning environments in building such confidence and motivation.  It helped build a University-community collaboration centered on student-led and designed Impactathons, which focused on community organizations efforts to address real-world problems.  The rigorous evaluation process helped document how peer-to-peer and near-to-peer learning structures in applied social change contexts can help build young people's motivation, self-confidence, and learning achievements in the use of digital technologies.
